vectorData.altText:
26. You put your granny’s cookie in your mouth, but can’t taste it with the anterior 2/3 of your tongue on the left.
Which cranial nerve do you suspect is not functioning properly? 
Cranial nerve __#___, the _____ nerve, on the _____ side.
(3 answers; separate with one space)
That is incorrect. Click here      to learn the answer, then come back to try again.
That's right!  The facial nerve, CN VII, receives taste sensation from the anterior 2/3 of the tongue on the ipsilateral side (in this case, left).

Cranial nerve VII, the facial nerve     , controls the muscles of facial expression. These are the muscles that allow us to close our eyes and mouth, smile or show our teeth, and raise our eyebrows, for instance     . If the facial nerve is lesioned, the ipsilateral face is weakened or paralyzed, and these movements cannot be performed     .
Again, the name reflects the function of the nerve!
The muscles of facial expression are distinct from the muscles of mastication, which are controlled by the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, V3.
Ask the patient to raise their eyebrows and show their teeth; with a lesion of the facial nerve, only one side of their face moves.

The facial nerve also carries parasympathetic preganglionic fibres destined to control secretion of the lacrimal, submandibular and sublingual glands, as well as the mucosa of the nasal and oral cavities.
The facial nerve receives taste sensation from the anterior 2/3 of the tongue.
Finally, as noted previously, it carries general sensory fibres from portions of the external ear.
This leaves only three cranial nerves to introduce! These are the nerves that are more of a mixed bag. We’ll start with cranial nerve VII, the facial nerve.
